Really great follow up to Half-Life, new weapons are great, level design is interesting and the platforming is solid.

This game is the superior add-on for half life. It has a great amount of guns, old and new, new enemy types, different level design (although more free to explore but can get lost sometimes),fully voice acted. The only problem is that there isn't a remake of it and it's brothers, blue shift and decay (why won't they release this? WE NEED IT!). It is wonky here and there due to Goldsrc not having the same power as today's engines (etc. No physics) and the enemy AI, but also the friendly, can be stupid (Friendly AI going straight to your trip mines). Despite that, it's a totally great game, classic masterpiece that everyone should play (it's even playable on a potato nowadays). It's cheap as heck and even cheaper on sales. Just buy it and see!

Opposing Force is basically the original Half-Life in a more compact form.
The kicker is that you play as the 'bad guys' from the original, the HECU Marines.

You take control of Corporal Adrian Shephard, a 22 year old Marine sent headfirst into the aftermath of the Black Mesa incident. Fighting creatures from Xen, Black ops, and a new species known as Race X, OpFor details the journey of survival taken by Shephard trying to survive in a 'hazardous environment'

You gain access to a number of new weapons like the wrench, sniper rifle, and M249 machine gun as well as a number of other cool toys. Adrian's arsenal also shares some similarities to Gordon's with returning favourites such as the SPAS-12 and the Glock.

Opposing Force is short but sweet, and a definite must play for fans of Half-Life or fans of FPS games in general.

9/10

explore the new world of half life in a different perspectives,rather than scientist or the black mesa personnel,you now play as a military guy seen in orignal half life, you play as hecu units,and you were send to silence the facility without knowing it, but things turned the wrong way when the resonance cascade hit. and your only objectives is to survives. [h1]Half-Life: Opposing Force[/h1]
*SciFi Action von 1999.

UrsprÃ¼nglich als Add-on zu Half-Life, ist es nun ein eigenstÃ¤ndiges Spiel. Gespielt wird wieder in der Black Mesa Research Facility. 
Du schlÃ¼pfst in die Rolle von Corporal Adrian Shephard, ein TeamfÃ¼hrer der US Marines. Und das ist echt gut gelungen. 

Der Name Opposing Force ist eine Anspielung auf ein physikalisches PhÃ¤nomen. Opposing Force spielt dabei auf das dritte Newtonsche Gesetz an, wo die entgegengerichtete Kraft im Englischen â€Opposing Forceâ€œ genannt wird.
Aber das nur so am Rande als Hintergrundwissen.

Das Spiel beinhaltet neue taktische MÃ¶glichkeiten: So ist es jetzt mÃ¶glich, an Seilen hochzuklettern oder sich von einem Seil zum nÃ¤chsten zu schwingen. Zudem ist hÃ¤ufig die Zusammenarbeit mit anderen Soldaten notwendig, um z. B. einen gemeinsamen Angriff zu starten oder sich von einem Pionier eine verschlossene TÃ¼r aufschweiÃŸen zu lassen. HÃ¤ufig findet man auch SanitÃ¤ter, die neben UnterstÃ¼tzung mit der Pistole auch Heilung von Wunden bieten.

Zudem gibt es auch neue Arten von auÃŸerirdischen Gegnern. Anders als bei Half-Life selbst, wurden die menschlichen Gegner in der deutschen Version diesmal nicht durch Roboter ersetzt.

Das Spiel setzt nicht die Handlung fort, sondern sie verlÃ¤uft parallel zu den Ereignissen von Half-Life. WÃ¤hrend Gordon Freeman durch Black Mesa eilt, wirst du als Shephard mit einem Team dorthin geschickt, um den Wissenschaftler auszuschalten. Die Transportmaschine wird jedoch beschossen und stÃ¼rzt ab. Du muÃŸt dich alleine durch Black Mesa schlagen, wobei dich nicht nur auÃŸerirdische Wesen aufhalten, sondern auch die Black Ops. Diese wurden geschickt, um nicht nur die VorgÃ¤nge in Black Mesa zu vertuschen, sondern auch die Marines auszuschalten, die daran beteiligt waren.

Du kehrst als MilitÃ¤rspezialist zur Black Mesa Research Facility zurÃ¼ck. Dein Auftrag: Gordon Freeman zu eliminieren.

[h1] Half-Life: Opposing Force [/h1]
* SciFi Action from 1999.

Originally an add-on to Half-Life, it is now a standalone game. Again, the game is played in the Black Mesa Research Facility.
You take on the role of Corporal Adrian Shephard, a team leader in the US Marines. And that worked out really well.

The name opposing force is an allusion to a physical phenomenon. Opposing force alludes to Newton's third law, where the opposing force is called "opposing force" in English.
But only as a side note as background knowledge.

The game includes new tactical options: It is now possible to climb up ropes or swing from one rope to the next. In addition, cooperation with other soldiers is often necessary in order to e.g. B. to launch a joint attack or to have a pioneer weld a locked door open. Often one can also find paramedics who offer not only support with the pistol but also healing of wounds.

There are also new types of alien enemies. In contrast to Half-Life itself, this time the human opponents were not replaced by robots in the German version.

The game does not continue the storyline, but rather runs parallel to the events of Half-Life. While Gordon Freeman rushes through Black Mesa, you are sent there as Shephard with a team to take down the scientist. However, the transport machine is shot at and crashes. You have to fight your way alone through Black Mesa, where you are not only stopped by extraterrestrial beings, but also by the Black Ops. These were sent to not only cover up what was going on at Black Mesa, but also to take out the Marines who were involved.

You return to the Black Mesa Research Facility as a military specialist. Your mission: to eliminate Gordon Freeman.
... nope, I won't tell any further.
So get up and find out for yourself what's going on.
Ingeniously made, very funny FPS, with depth.

If you liked Half-Life or Black Mesa Source you're gonna like this, this expansion adds upon the original with a new perspective, new weapons, a long campaign, and new bits of lore surrounding the Black mesa Incident.
you dont just play as god you play as the person you send to FUCKING KILL GOD

This game makes you think alot different about the HECU, aka the guys that go shooting at you because you saw the xen, or the aliens. Before playing this game, you would think "F*CK THE HECU" this game brought you you by Valve changes it all, you would soon be like "Damn, now I see how they feel about the black mesa incident" and if you are going to get the game to have an easier half life, that isnt gonna be how it is, since you are going to be fighting alot more aliens, and have little to no HECU helping, the game involves more strategy than the normal half life, and I dont want to spoil a bit of the game, but we can agree how the GMAN might be behind your Missing In Action status, I recommend this game because, One why the hell not? More half life, and you see the HECU's point of view, Two You play as Adrian Shepard, someone that might be worth knowing if Half Life 3 comes out (which you can tell Valve cares about half life from Half life Alyx, something else could be coming) Three, if Operation Black Mesa is a bust (which it probably wont be, and it might never come out) you have this game
If you love playing the original half life and the other expansion pack blue shift then this is for you playing as cpl Shepard showcasing his story during the black mesa incident

Jesus, this was dreadful. The combat was nowhere near the quality of Blue Shift. And the generic soldiers don't make it any better. And the new enemies don't have any uniqueness to their design, except for the bugs that drop from the shock troopers, which are used way too much throughout. Even then, I don't find fighting them fun, or tense, it just feels needlesly infuriating. Roughly the first half (hehe) of the campaign is really good, but it just gets overly frustrating by the end. Overall, it's still Half-Life, but it's the lowpoint of the series for me. THANKS, R A N D Y
